node.title: PG&E electrical equipment sparked massive Dixie Fire in California
node.description: The fire, which started on July 13, burned more than 900,000 acres and destroyed hundreds of buildings.
node.content: ["The California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection announced Tuesday that last year's devastating Dixie Fire began when a tree came in contact with an electrical line owned and operated by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company. The blaze, which started on July 13, was one of the\u00a0largest fires\u00a0ever recorded in the state.", "Cal Fire has been investigating the cause of the Dixie Fire for months. The fire burned 963,309 acres across Butte, Plumas, Lassen, Shasta and Tehama County, destroyed 1,329 structures and left 95 damaged. The fire burned for more than 100 days until it was finally 100% contained on October 25.", "Last year, PG&E acknowledged that its equipment may have been to blame for the Dixie Fire.", "No charges were announced in Tuesday's press release.", "However, PG&E has faced a slew of charges for its role in previous wildfires. Last year, it was charged with manslaughter and other crimes after the 2020 Zogg Fire, sparked by PG&E equipment, killed several people. A year earlier, PG&E\u00a0pleaded guilty\u00a0to 84 counts of involuntary manslaughter after a 2018 blaze, ignited by its long-neglected electrical grid, and devastated the town of Paradise.\u00a0", "PG&E had previously filed for bankruptcy, but reemerged in 2020 after negotiating a\u00a0$13.5 billion settlement\u00a0with some wildfire victims.", "Sophie Reardon is a News Editor at CBS News. Reach her at sophie.reardon@viacomcbs.com"]
